abstract.text: A container for vertex data forming part of the definition for a three-dimensional object, or geometry.

inlineContent.text: You use geometry sources together with
objects or to inspect the data that composes an existing geometry.
You create a custom geometry using a three-step process:
objects containing vertex data. Each geometry source defines an attribute, or semantic, of the vertices it describes. You must provide at least one geometry source, using the
semantic, to create a custom geometry; typically you also provide geometry sources for surface normals and texture coordinates.
object, containing an array of indices identifying vertices in the geometry sources and describing the drawing primitive that SceneKit uses to connect the vertices when rendering the geometry.
instance from the geometry sources and geometry elements.

Because most geometries use more than one geometry source and the GPU typically uses data from multiple sources together, you can achieve better rendering performance for custom geometries by interleaving the vertex data for multiple semantics in the same array.
To do this, first create an array where each element contains values for multiple semantics for the same vertex. Next, create an
object from that array, and create each geometry source from that data using the

parameters to specify where the values for each semantic can be found in the array. To make specifying the sizes and locations of vectors more convenient, you can define your own data structure for vertices and use the
Listing 1. Creating multiple geometry sources from interleaved data

abstract.text: A static byte buffer that bridges to ; use  when you need reference semantics or other Foundation-specific behavior.
Create 3D games and add 3D content to apps using high-level scene descriptions, and easily add animations, physics simulation, particle effects, and realistic physically based rendering.
A three-dimensional shape (also called a model or mesh) that can be displayed in a scene, with attached materials that define its appearance.
A container for index data describing how vertices connect to define a three-dimensional object, or geometry.
A container for vertex data forming part of the definition for a three-dimensional object, or geometry.
The semantic for vertex position data.
The size, in bytes, of each vector component.
The number of scalar components in each vector.
The data for the geometry source.
The offset, in bytes, from the beginning of the data to the first vector component to be used in the geometry source.
The number of bytes from a vector to the next one in the data.
Creates a geometry source from an array of normal vectors.
Creates a geometry source from an array of texture coordinate points.
Creates a geometry source from an array of vertex positions.
Creates a geometry source whose vertex data resides in the specified Metal buffer, allowing modification through a Metal compute shader.
Creates a geometry source from the specified data and options.
Creates a geometry source from an array of normal vectors.
Creates a geometry source from an array of texture coordinate points.
Creates a geometry source from an array of vertex positions.
The semantic value (or attribute) the geometry source describes for each vertex.
A Boolean value that indicates whether vector components are floating-point values.
The number of vectors in the data.
Basic shapes—such as spheres, boxes, and planes—and features for generating 3D objects from 2D text and Bézier curves.
The root class of most Objective-C class hierarchies, from which subclasses inherit a basic interface to the runtime system and the ability to behave as Objective-C objects.
A protocol that enables an object to be encoded and decoded for archiving and distribution.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A protocol that enables encoding and decoding in a manner that is robust against object substitution attacks.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.

value.text: A static byte buffer in memory.
